Authors:
Tiara Sousa Cabral, Maria P Martin, Charles Roland Clement,
Kentaro Hosaka, Iuri Goulart Baseia
Title:
Multiple loci and morphology reveal a new species and hidden
diversity in the genus Xylophallus (Phallomycetidae, Basidiomycota)
Abstract:
The Amazon rainforest is the largest Neotropical Biome and
plays essential roles in terrestrial carbon storage and climate.
Although it is a highly biodiverse biome, the diversity and distribution
of fungal species are still poorly known. The Amazon rainforest is being
deforested and habitat fragmentation is a serious threat for mycobiota.
Information about fungal species diversity and distribution in Amazonia
is important, as they are important ecosystem members. Xylophallus
xylogenus is the smallest phalloid fungi described to date. Xylophallus
was considered monospecific and is geographically restricted to the
Neotropics. During field trips in Amazonia, numerous specimens of
Xylophallus with great morphological diversity were collected. We
evaluated six independent DNA regions, including ITS, and their power
for discovering putative species in the genus. We also estimated the
species trees for the genus and we tested competing models of species
delimitation using Bayes factors. The results reveal the presence of
three evolutionary units within the genus: one is X. xylogenus; another
clade is a new species, here named Xylophallus clavatus; the third clade
appears to be a cryptic species Â– the first recorded in phalloid fungi.
These findings demonstrate the mycological richness of Neotropical
forests.
